noun.description: A small bomb made of a metal or wooden box filled with powder, used to blast down a door or to make a hole in a wall.

phrases: Charges of working against the interests of your own country are very slippery things, and may get the one making the charges hoisted by his own petard someday.
He's been at if for years and he finally got hoisted by his own petard.
But it is hard not to enjoy the fact that liberals now find themselves hoist by their own petard.
But, with any luck, he may soon be hoisted by his own petard.
I've been hoist by my own petard many times, McCain said, musing, but if I think a thing is not right, I have my say.
origin: Mid 16th century: from French pétard, from péter break wind.
